stem: The nurse is evaluating the effectiveness of interventions for hyperkalemia. Review the clinical data from 0800 to 1100. Which finding most clearly indicates a therapeutic response to the interventions?

options.text: T wave amplitude increasing from 6 mm to 8 mm.
QRS interval widening from 0.10 seconds to 0.12 seconds.
Serum potassium level decreasing from 6.8 mEq/L to 5.2 mEq/L.
Heart rate decreasing from 88 bpm to 72 bpm with persistent peaked T waves.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 0745: SBAR report from night shift. Patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD) admitted for hyperkalemia. Patient reports muscle weakness. ECG shows peaked T waves. Kayexalate and insulin/dextrose ordered. 0800: Kayexalate 30g administered rectally. Insulin 10 units IV and D50W IV administered. Patient reports continued weakness. 0930: Patient reports slight improvement in muscle strength. Repeat ECG shows tall T waves, less peaked. 1100: Patient states feeling much better; muscle weakness improved. ECG shows T waves less prominent.

tabs.title: Provider Orders
tabs.content:
• Kayexalate 30 grams PR q6h PRN for K+ > 5.5 mEq/L
  • Insulin Regular 10 units IV stat, followed by D50W IV stat
  • Continuous ECG monitoring
  • Repeat serum potassium q2h

rationale.correctRationale: A decreasing serum potassium level from 6.8 mEq/L at 0800 to 5.2 mEq/L at 1100 most clearly indicates a therapeutic response to the interventions (Kayexalate and insulin/dextrose). The primary goal of treatment for hyperkalemia is to reduce the potassium level to a safer range, thereby reducing the risk of cardiac complications.

incorrectRationales.option_1: Increasing T wave amplitude indicates worsening hyperkalemia, not a therapeutic response. T wave changes are a key ECG manifestation of hyperkalemia, and an increase suggests the condition is deteriorating.
incorrectRationales.option_2: Widening QRS interval also suggests worsening hyperkalemia and potential cardiac conduction abnormalities. This is an adverse sign that requires immediate attention.
incorrectRationales.option_4: While a decreasing heart rate can be a positive sign in some contexts, the presence of persistent peaked T waves indicates that hyperkalemia is still affecting the heart. The potassium level itself needs to decrease for a true therapeutic response.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Students may focus solely on ECG changes without considering the potassium level, which is the most direct indicator of treatment success. They may also fail to recognize the trend of the potassium level over time and its significance in evaluating treatment effectiveness.

clinicalPearls: During hyperkalemia treatment, closely monitor serial potassium levels, ECG changes, and patient-reported symptoms such as muscle weakness. Be vigilant for signs of hypokalemia (e.g., muscle cramps, weakness, arrhythmias) after treatment.
